job_title: Guest Services Manager in Fayetteville, AR
pros: Flexibilty / Easy Job Tasks
cons: Working here is easy but who can live off of $11/hr nowadays? Sometimes the families are super rude and triple our workload- (lice issues, bed bugs, stealing food donations, donors not showing up the day they were supposed to provide a meal and we are the ones having to end up cooking for 20+ mouths in such a short time frame, etc) I can tell when "important" people are visiting the program when I see snacks and drinks filling up our kitchen that I never see stocked year round, unless donated (body armor drinks, yoplaits, Capri Suns). Also the Soiree and Shindig events are a joke. RMHC of Arkoma "features" a family that stayed with us in those events (non shockingly a family with lots of followers and obviously have a "heavy wallet." One of the biggest highlights of this event is to showcase this family. Here's the kicker- The staff that actually took care of the selected RMHC of Arkoma families - us who make $11/hr receive NO recognition. We don't even get invited. The people getting clapped at these galas are the hypocrites in the leadership team who work behind the scenes. They never had the parents cry on their shoulder, ask for help, or even comfort them when their child is still not breathing on his own. Even leadershhip staff from a different location get to attend. It was infuriating and confusing. This company just leaches off of college student cheap labor. Tori who is on the leadership team comes in 20 minutes late allll the time too. Enough was enough. I can't be in a company that will leach off of my hospitality and hard work to their own advantage.

pros: Flexible hours Good Friends Decent Pay Discounts Friendly STaff
cons: Long Days' Customers Hot Environment In Summer Rude People Greasy Food

review_title: Senior Leadership does not treat employees with dignity
pros: The mission is very important
cons: Ronald McDonald House Charities of San Diego has a reputation of being fire-happy. High performing employees get terminated without warning for no reason and without severance. This is not a friendly work environment that fosters professional growth. The organization's treatment of high functioning and contributing employees is dehumanizing and disgraceful. Senior Leadership in the Philanthropy Department specifically is ineffective, dysfunctional and dishonest, creating a chaotic and inefficient work environment for Philanthropy team members. From a business standpoint, the organization misuses resources and has irresponsible and inhumane Human Resource practices.

pros: Great organization full of great people.
cons: Slow at times for an intern

pros: RMHC of Greater Chattanooga is a phenomenal place to work in Chattanooga. Not only is it recognized as "Best Non-Profit" by the city, but it also has a wonderful staff and mission. Benefits are incredible, the small team feels like a family, support from the community and global RMHC is so helpful, and everything is so fun!
cons: Non-profit will never be able to pay what you could in the corporate world. It's just a reality, BUT the connections you make with this organization will further your career more than you can imagine. The connections with the board, donors. volunteers, companies that want to help, it's overwhelming in the best way!

job_title: Operations Associate in Long Beach, CA
pros:
- Get to know very loving families during long term + short term stays
- Very fulfilling position working with families and getting to know several very long term
- Great working with volunteers in the community.
cons:
-Alone on the job for 8+ hours while in charge of supervising the house that could contain over 28 families ranging in size from 1-6.
-potentially very late hours
-Sometimes dangerous situations late at night without any formal training.
- Most of the shift was spent cleaning rooms
- No Growth opportunities
- Often working over 8+ hours into midnight if the next operations associate working the midnight shift does not show up.
- Labor heavy (cleaning)
- Emotionally exhausting position with no training or external resources for mental health.
- Extremely low paying for responsibilities.

review_title: Impactful Organization with Amazing Leadership and Team

pros: A culture of teamwork, shared purpose and vision. The work is meaningful and the CEO puts the mission at the heart of the work we are all engaged in.
cons: I have no cons to working at RMHC of the Intermountain Area. It consistently is rated as the top workplace in Salt Lake City through anonymous surveys of the staff, staff stays at the organization for a long time and are able to find opportunities to grow and thrive, and you feel like you are making the world a better place by spending your time and talents in this work.

review_title: Surprisingly poorly managed despite being a large non profit
pros: The work itself is easy, but you will be doing a lot of work that doesn’t really fit the job description. The families are usually great to work with. Lots of downtime if you are a student.
cons: Minimum wage for a mentally depressing job. Yes, you will meet people who lose their child. High turnover rate due to poor management. You sit by yourself managing a building with 40 rooms in it. Sometimes there are problems that come up and management is unavailable. Unfortunately, there are families that take advantage of the free services they are getting and actually negatively impact the other families. You will see the worst in people despite folks being there because their child/children are very sick. People stealing food from other families, folks smoking in their rooms despite children having lung/heart problems. It’s very unfortunate.

review_title: Very, very stressful. Low pay and limited room for growth.
job_title: Fundraising and Events Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: Loved how sweet my coworkers were and the mission is incredible! A few great managers and understanding people.
cons: Very old school ways of fundraising and very, very stressful environment. Very much a "let's burn you out" vibe, at least on my team. Several times while working there I ended up in urgent care with chest pains, neck pains, and other issues, always related to stress at work. Limited work life balance and pathways for growth or learning were few and far between. Innovation and new ideas are not welcomed or encouraged. They talk about how much they care for their team, but the actions do not follow. A culture of fear, micromanagement, and "don't speak up" rules most of the organization.

review_title: Charity doesn’t care about workers and always sides with management
pros: Met a few nice people working there, was able to support vulnerable people which was rewarding.
cons: This charity employs some right plonkers for their management team. It became like a communist regime in there, not allowed to speak your mind or have an opinion. They don’t appreciate loyalty or hard work. Worked there for 18 months and received no training whatsoever that was promised. Often lone working. Awful shift patterns. No sick pay. Would not recommend getting a job here.

pros: Fun, fantastic, diverse, great, perfect
cons: Smell, scent, taste, height, style

review_title: Okay but be careful of phoney management
pros: Employees care about the families and what they are doing.
cons:
Management will smile in your face and  roll out the red carpet in your first couple of weeks hoping you will stay there... but in a nice way later they change everything. All the smiles dont mean anything when your fake (no one smiles that much). Also don't give a 2 weeks notice that you need to leave the company because they may let you go the same day you give your resignation. Sad thing is they dont act concerned as to what's going on just ASSUME your not happy and dont want to be there...Fake..(no wonder they kept being surprised I kept returning to worknas though people never come back) Now I see why! Beware!

Benefits are okay if no family and you dont need to see doctor much...but they have 4 plans and it defaults to 1, you cant choose the others, it will not allow you to choose what you want and the deductible is too high even though they pay toward your preimum..your premium still adds up and so does a high deductible.! The one with the low deductible is only $9 more per paycheck and you cant choose that so it's not worth it either. 

I saw the meanness in people even after I was told they were really nice...phoney. I like how the truth comes out at some point...but we have options in life.

pros: Very good management and nice colleagues. Working environment is also super good.
cons: I had to commute an hour.

job_title: Fire Life Safety Director in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, some of the Directors are excellent to work with, meet lot of great people
cons: Some co workers are very gossipy, environment can be unhealthy because of that. Unhealthy competitions

pros: the working environment is quite good
cons: work is repetitive and can feel boring

pros: There was always a good sense of purpose being able to help those in need.
cons: It can be stressful to work with people who are in terribly rough situations somedays.

pros: Nothing at all this place stinks.
cons: Everything it all is terrible.

pros: great people, great job, wonderful opportunity

job_title: Family Room Manager in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Fun and meaningful work and hands on time with families
cons: May have to work unexpected hours and often over 40 hours a week

pros:

pros: great organizaton. My favorite everyone is so nice and fun to work with

job_title: Immigration Lawyer in San Diego, CA
pros: I've loved working here, it's been great.

job_title: Part Time Service Crew in Alabang
pros: There are no pros in this company

review_title: Great mission but trouble leveraging this to long-term fundraising
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oak Brook, IL
pros:
Fantastic mission.
Great staff who are committed to the work and families.
Solid brand. 
New facilities and growth.
Relatively committed board.
Decent compensation.
cons:
Too reliant on event fundraising.
Goes to same donors over and over with little to no strategy.
Has Raisers Edge, but not utilizing it for anything other than capturing donor contact info and gifts.
CEO comes from advertising world and manages staff under "projects" rather than general accountabilities (i.e. rather than an event "team" working together on all events, one person runs the golf event, one runs the gala, etc.).
High mid-to-senior level fundraiser turnover (seven have come and gone, often with no explanation, in eight years).
Majority of development staff has no fundraising experience from outside the organization.
High expectations to work and attend all the events the organization has, most on evenings and weekends (more of these events than similar organizations).
Not a revenue-generating charity (doesn't charge for services) so entirely reliant on successful fundraising. A bad year means staff has to be cut.

pros: Horrible There’s nothing to say
cons: Low pay, horrible bosses and all higher up, the employees never show up for there shift

pros: Its ok but really needs to improve
cons: No respect for the employees by managers

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- Mission is meaningful and clearly demonstrated every day. 
- Opportunity to learn and grow is immense-  promotions, opportunities to work with every team, serve on committees etc. 
- Many on the team are great to work with- informal mentorship opportunities and relationships developed, peer-to-peer relationships have been extremely rewarding and productive, and even working with our corporate partners and volunteers!
- While at a chapter, working locally and independent ally of nationals, having access to those best practices and professionals across the county and the world
cons:
- Could be more strategic in thinking and planning. Some times projects lose steam and get stuck and have the wrong people leading them. 
- Lots of transition and change right now- need to be patient and ride the waves of change a bit. 
- few (very few) with poor attitudes- problems not always dealt with in timely manner
- Comp will typically always be a bit lower in a nonprofit (but great benefits offered at this particular chapter that help to make up for it...)

pros: This organization is dedicated to a necessary and very worthy cause. The families who stay at the house are so grateful for the opportunity to keep families together at home away form home. Many of the locations offer so many services to help the families cope and have access to everyday supplies along with free meals. Staff is always so giving and willing to extend a helping hand!
cons: Executive staff is not open to ideas from staff below them who work in the trenches seeing what goes on where. Depending on the community the house is located in the salaries can be a challenge for staff to make ends meet. There is no room for career advancement or flexibility to redefine roles for promotions.

pros: The mission, committees and the board of directors are for the most part legit
cons: No direction, no training, horrible communication, gossip and backstabbing by some staff including Ex Director.  Only half the staff has passion for the cause and other half only care about money and community recognition.

review_title: A Welcoming Place Caring for Families
job_title: Resident Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The organization is run well given the small staff they have. Though everyone has their individual roles, everyone helps each other with other duties. Busy times can be stressful, but their incredible teamwork helps and your coworkers become like your family.
cons: Depending on your responsibilities, any downtime is best used to catch up on projects that could easily fall behind. There is always something/ someone that needs your attention. Any position you work here is great for someone who loves to be involved in helping/ supporting families, but it can burn you out at times. Pace yourself with learning and find your rhythm.

pros: Helping families in need. Seeing cute kids playing and interacting.
cons:
Abusive, secretive practises from the CEO. While most of your coworkers are decent people. You never know where you stand with the CEO, therefore your relationship with your director or manager seems unbalanced.
A common practice is to accuse you or your coworkers in private or at team meetings of not being team players or gossiping. The CEO will then try to isolate these coworkers by telling them to keep this conversation private, as you don’t know what your coworkers may be dealing with personally. The mention of these conversations could compile negative feelings for them.
This isolating move seems like a tactic to make you feel insecure about your future. Meaning you would be less likely to ask for pay increases, support or supplies.
It might take you months to notice the toxic behaviour but it’s there.

pros: A very caring environment. Employees get the best of insurance rates and 30 paid days of leave to take for holidays, illness, or annual leave. We also experience the best of humanity through the very strong volunteer and donation program plus the families are generally grateful for the support found there. Feels like getting paid to be a part of something great
cons: Dealing with occasional ungrateful and/or entitled individuals who don't appreciate the opportunity to stay at RMH. It's a charity so over and above is always expected in time and effort spent there and the pay is not that competitive

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for and I'd probably never leave
pros: My job is simply overnight security. I also do some light cleaning that don't disturb guests at night. I love that I don't have many issues to deal with in the night time because I am by myself. Breakfast volunteers are always a plus in the morning! This job offers so many benefits like: free tickets to local shows and entertainment. bonuses, and the ability to fill job positions if someone wants to take a day off or decides to pursue other opportunities. RMH would rather hire within before hiring outside.
cons: This place houses kids that need hospital treatment. It's hard trying to not be emotional. Also it is scary at night by yourself.

pros:
I have worked at the the Philadelphia Ronald McDonald House for several years, and these are my opinions:

Pros: Great mission, rewarding to help others, good benefits paid 100% by employer for employee 
( dependents are extra and very expensive ), and free lunch most days.
cons: Cons: Management and employee culture are highly dysfunctional. Abusive behavior such as yelling, threatening, and other hostile actions are tolerated by upper management and are a normal, everyday part of work at PRMH. Hiring practices are inconsistent and questionable, resulting in people being put into positions they are ill-suited for. Leadership is conflict-avoidant and focused primarily on fundraising, so staff problems run rampant and are not properly addressed. The toxic work culture at PRMH is not befitting of it's great mission, and scares away good employees.

pros: It was an amazing organization to be a part of. Working in the same house as the families was inspiring. We got left over from the dinner groups for lunch every day.
cons: The CEO was useless, and during my time at the House, there was extreme turnover. Overall, the company culture was horrible. I constantly felt like I had to defend myself, and my expertise was never taken seriously. I would make suggestions, or implement ideas and be shut down by another employee because they didn't agree, even though I was doing the job I was hired to do.

pros: The idea of this place is awesome, the intent to support families is wonderful. The work that is done is extraordinary and it is a very easy idea to sell and raise money for.
cons: The major challenge with this position was that part-time staff was considered to be 'beneath' regular staff and were treated very poorly. Since I started, the entire organization has seen at least 75 percent turn over. Beware of management, stay on their good side if you want to keep working there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Helping Families in need, meeting people that want to help. Working with people (staff, volunteers) that believe in the mission and are dedicated to it is inspiring
cons: There is a disconnection between the mission and how upper management deals with the families. Their main focus is on looks and raising money, but they are forgetting about the most important thing, which is how the families and staff feels. Staff is underpaid, overworked, and mistreated by management. There are not leaders, the lack of communication between departments is high. Talented, experienced hard working staff are leaving the organization in high numbers, especially Operations and Programs Departments. It is very sad that the Board allows this to happen, power and ego runs the organization. Higher Management doesn't want smart, independent thinkers, they are too hard to control and manipulate. If staff members express any type of  disagreement, they are told "The Door is Open, you are free to go if you don't like it"  The Staff is afraid of speaking their minds, because of fear of losing their jobs. Salary disparity between upper Management, Management Favorites, and the rest of the staff is out of control. A change is needed, and needed soon. Board Members need to wake up, your building a castle with no heart inside. The heart of the house is the staff and the families, and if they're not treated with love and respect, the organization will fail. This kind of management cannot last for much longer.

pros: Nothing beats the feeling of knowing you are working for the greater good of others. Working with like minded people who are compassionate, kind and friendly. Starting to focus more resources now on People Development and connecting across Australia which is fantastic. Really friendly and social with regular lunches, afternoon nibbles on a  Friday and more.
cons: Being a not-for-profit can sometimes feel behind in resourcing and technology but that does allow for more creativity. Sometimes a lack of accountability.

review_title: Great Mission but no leadership, no accountability, inequality of pay
pros: Support for families in their time of need, fast-paced environment, each day brings new challenges and is never dull.  I met people from around the world who have changed my life.  The mission is what makes this organization great.
cons: Blatant nepotism by leadership, pay is not based on the quality of work, organization structure too top-heavy, job responsibilities not clearly defined.  Each House runs differently, hopefully this is not how all Houses operate.

pros: The cause and the environment.
cons: No opportunity for growth, no work life balance, not much opportunity for professional development. A lot of staff at all levels are over-worked. This organization is open 365 days of the year, so working part time means you work all statutory holidays. You can work horrible, ungodly hours as well and it won't be reflected in your pay. Upper level staff are also overworked and often express having to work on their days off... Aka coming in on weekdays.

review_title: If you want a job to pay the bills, this works.  If you want anything meaningful or challenging, keep looking.
pros: This company cannot fail.  Even if the local office does not raise enough money, McDonald's Corporation will not let the charity fail.  It can't - because it's name is attached to it.
cons:
I spent more time trying to look busy than actually doing any work.  My position was presented in the interview as a position where I could use my skills to make a meaningful contribution.  I would be a part of decision-making and strategy development.  In reality, I was a gopher. 

The talk about how they are changing lives.  Give me a break - they are a hotel.

pros: The world the Ronald McDonald House does is great- it is very rewarding to help families during tough times.  Some Houses are large, if you want more of a hotel feel, some are small if you want more of a home feel.
cons: All Chapters are independently run so they are all very very different in how they operate, raise funds, manage money, pay employees, etc. There is little to no communication between houses.

review_title: Love the job, not the pay.
pros: Great mission with pleasant staff and appreciative guests. Comfortable, homelike setting.
cons: I have been a weekend manager for over five years, but am still making less than $12/hr. Raises are usually <.25 cents/hr. The perks are that I do get paid for the sleep time and meals, but I have to rely on the overtime to make this work. No insurance, or PTO or bonuses.

review_title: Working at Ronald McDonald House was a great experience in helping families with critically ill children.
pros: Great, dedicated staff.  Flexibility and ability to adjust hours to meet work and family needs.  Mission based employment with ability to help families in need.
cons: Politics between corporate, hospital partners and local board and staff.  Difficult to meet all demands when coming from so many directions.  Compensation was low with lack of respect for professionalism of staff at times.

pros:
great cause
money went to making sure kids had a home
awesome volunteers and events
management listened
coworkers were fully invested in the mission
cons:
things were a bit quiet and slow moving sometimes
lots of donors to cater to, sometimes felt that the donors were doing it to feel good about themselves, and less for the kids

review_title: Privileged to Be Apart of the Team
job_title: Communications Coordinator in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: Uniquely structured like a corporation. Phenomenal organizational support from top executives. Unwavering mission to serve millions of families globally each year.
cons: RMHC has an amazing track record of keeping administrative costs at a minimum. Though this is something to definitely be proud of, it unfortunately keeps our salaries at a minimum as well.

pros: Great organization. Volunteered in the front office of a local house and the full-time staff were some of the best people I've ever worked with.
cons: Really nothing bad to say. I wish they had more legitimate internships at local houses, not just volunteer opportunities. Work was sometimes very very boring.

job_title: Guest Service Associate in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: Caring for out of county families with sick children. Community Support for fundraising events.   Getting to witness the recovery of a child. Assisting families with paper scheduling, questions and inquiries.
cons: During the interview process I was told I would cover weekends once a month in rotation.  Upon hire I noticed I was scheduled to work weekdays and full weekends 2 to 3 times a month.  Disorganized management and lack of communication between day shift and night shift.

review_title: Beneficial, gives you the tools to succeed.
pros: Give you the tools to succeed.  Allows for advancement with hard work.  Co-workers are helpful when learning the ropes.  Team Environment.
cons: Often feel alone at times and help isn't readily available.  Must be able to think on your feet and able to handle a fast paced environment,

pros: Helps families who's children are going through a long term illness/surgery while they are away from home for extended periods.  Average stay is 6-12 months.  They live at Ronald McDonald House and are provided apartments and have all meals/living supplies, transportation to medical facilities, school for siblings, activities for children and outings for families. Other financial help is available also.  A very warm and loving environment.
cons: I wish it was bigger so there wasn't a waiting list.

pros: Everyone is very nice and works very hard to take care of the families who stay.   It's easy to see how important the work that happens there is.
cons: Development is such a large focus that it can often feel like a corporate atmosphere.  There is little room for career growth.

job_title: Guest Service Associate in Denver, CO
pros: Helping families of sick children.
cons:
Forced to work hours past scheduled shift until relief shows, so etimes being around 12:15am when they should have been there at 11pm.

No room for growth even with expanding business.

Hours are never certain, always up in the air. Cannot have a second job while working here as staying late has effected other job.

review_title: Wonderful mission, each House operates separately so make sure the House you work at is financially sound.
pros: Helping the families in times of crisis - seeing lots of children playing and having fun.
cons:
Did not know upon hire the financial situation with the House.  Upper management was changed, Found out that the Development Dept. did not work together and there was separation and tension.
Staff turnover very high - bad communication with other departments.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Working for a company that cares for families and children. Looks good on resume because of what the organization stands for.
cons: There is very limited room for advancement. You would think because of how well known the organization is known, the employees would earn a decent salary, but the pay is low. Might be better off at a fast food restaurant.

pros: There is always a friendly atmosphere amongst colleagues and it's really uplifting to see all the families supporting one another. My confidence in myself and my ability to do my job well has significantly increased because of my supervisors and colleagues always giving me encouragement as well as providing professional development opportunities.
cons: I have no cons for my particular chapter of RMH

review_title: Having the ability to help others in need with sick children is a noble mission, but it is definitely a labor of love
pros:
Positive work environment 
Noble mission 
Mostly great co-workers 
Great healthcare plan
Looks great on a resume
Ability to meet people from all over the world and share in their triumphs and tribulations
cons:
The pay is pretty difficult to live off of 
There are constant changes/ updates of protocol
There are a bit of inconsistencies 
Sometimes emotionally stressful
Not much upward mobility

job_title: Human Resources Administrator in Pasadena, CA
pros: Seeing the kids and families you are working to serve makes all the challenges worthwhile. Benefits are good, location is great, everyone who works for the organization is connected to the cause and easily connects back to it after a hard day. It is also really cool to see the houses all over Southern California come together in this chapter setting and work toward a common goal.
cons: Time off policies are not very competitive.

pros: I cant say enough about working for this charity. The families are so grateful, the staff at the houses are devoted and caring and the charity corporate office is full of the most hardworking people ever.
cons: None. My experience was nothing, but amazing. Even being on call over night wasn't bad. Had there been a full-time position available, I would have tried my hardest to go for it.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros: I spent nearly six years working for RMHC-AR and loved every minute of it. The ability to work for an organization that provides such needed care and respite to families living through unspeakable hardship was both rewarding and humbling.
cons: Fortunately, there were more miracles than tragedies during my time at RMHC-AR, but the loss of a child never gets easier. It takes a strong person to work in such an environment.

pros: One of the most rewarding places I've ever worked at. My interaction with the families was the my favorite part of my experience and I look forward to any future assignments with the Ronald McDonald House.
cons: Sometimes you can get bored when the families are busy. Also, you can easily gain weight if  not careful with all the delicious food around the house. All in all, a great place with a great cause!

job_title: House Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great feeling when helping families in need.
cons: Not a good work environment most days. Teamwork is NOT key here. There’s more turn over in staff than expected. Call outs and not enough coverage.

pros: Great Mission and lovely families
cons: Management prefers to higher new people rather then promoting and training within. You will often feel like you are not being communicated to. Your pay will be low and your hours long. The  management is more like a social club. If you work in programs you will be working at a shared space, which is rather noisy and sits in the middle of a hall way.

pros: Everyone was friendly and caring- the mission of the organization is always at the forefront of everything everyone does.  Job responsibilities are clear and feedback is immediate and helpful. Staff are given authority to make decisions within their sphere.  Expect to happily work hard.
cons: People who have difficulty making decisions and who are not proactive struggle in this environment.

review_title: Only exists to make McDonalds look like they care
pros: Good health care and pension
cons: Management of the charity are useless...they should stick to selling burgers

review_title: Great work culture - RMHC OR & SW WA\
job_title: Guest Service Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros:
-wonderful PTO package (18 days PTO a year)
-I feel supported every day
-I leave work feeling like I made a difference in peoples' lives
-great advancement opportunities
cons: -Pay is a little bit lower than for-profit companies but the wages are still competitive

review_title: CEO/ Executive Director NEEDS TO GO
pros: The pro of working at this job was that you know that what you were doing really was making a difference in the lives of families in need. The staff in the houses were so wonderful- especially at the St. Pete houses and I'm still friends with two former coworkers. As far as non-profits go, the pay and benefits were very competitive and work/life balance was good and flexible. Also, 17 days of paid vacation time was almost unbeatable.
cons:
The con is that the Tampa Bay CEO's management style is nothing short of horrific. If you've seen Devil Wears Prada, that's what we're talking about. She will go out of her way to put you down at any chance she gets. I got to the point where I was having bouts of IBS brought on by the stress of working in an office where you never knew if it was your day to be publicly berated for no reason. This issue has since stopped now that I'm working in a supportive and healthy office environment. The CEO doesn't sleep and has major memory lapses. I managed to stay in the position for two years but there were 4 employees in my position in a 2 year period prior to me because no one could stand to work there with her. By the time I left, she was also ruining relationships with event venues and donors. 

There is also no room for upward mobility in this organization although that is not unique in the world of non-profits. 

Also, the National CEO has a very real issue with millenials which he made painfully clear in a workshop I was in with him at the national convention in Chicago.

review_title: RMHC of the Southwest is one of worst places you could work.
pros: Help families with sick children.
cons: RMHC of the Southwest was one of the most miserable places I have ever worked. Management lacks appreciation for their employees, the work they produce, the contributions they make and the time they give. There is no check and balances within the organization so expectations, measurables, and overall guidelines are not the same from one person to the next. The organization lacks structure and an efficient leader. The practices within RMHC of the Southwest are unethical, from cancelling benefit plans without telling their employees, to pulling retirement funds from their paychecks and NOT depositing the funds into their retirement plans, to holding young professionals to a standard not even they can meet. The culture within RMHC is one of gossip, backstabbing, and favoritism and it's all at the hands of the President & CEO. Please don't think you have an ally in HR either, whatever issue you have with the organization will be excused and twisted into a situation where you are the culprit in every situation. Everyone is to blame but upper management. Do not take a job at RMHC of the Southwest, you will be unhappy, overworked, underpaid, and for what? They have the lowest of low benefit plans, you get paid FAR below the average salary for your position, and you're forced to work weekend events and various after hour jobs with no extra pay or any comp time. Let numbers speak for themselves: in 2 years 22 people quit RMHC; 9 of the 22 in just 7 months. Working here was one of the biggest mistakes I've made in my professional career and I'd like to save someone else the time that I had to waste.

pros:
Great mission
Amazing staff and volunteers
Good pay and benefits
cons:
Everyone is overworked
Development department is very dysfunctional and there are some major sensitivity and HR violations going on
Not a supportive environment and rifts between teams
Leaders are out of touch with those who work on the ground
Inconsistent policies

review_title: Inspiring children to follow their dreams.
pros: Seeing friends and families love and help one another, learning to love myself in the process of helping others, remembering that life is beautiful.
cons: Keeping yourself positive during hard situations, not letting the situations define your own personal self-esteem.

pros: Great people doing great work for families that are in significant need of lodging, food and other services while in the middle of a child's medical crisis far from home.
cons: Limited advancement opportunity, work can be stressful, never enough hours in the day to do all that is needed for families or to raise enough funds.

pros: -It is clear that you are working for a worthy cause. Every story you hear is incredible.
cons: -Even though the purpose for working at a non-profit like RMH is absolutely rewarding, I didn't like how the staff never participated in after-hours volunteering with the residents. Not that there was a disconnect, but there was definitely a separation.

pros: It was a great place to feel as though you were making a difference.  I learned a lot and developed as a person
cons: Occasionally it could be frustrating to have so much red tape, and some of the other workers didn't show the same level of commitment, but that's sort of to be expected in a NFP.

pros: The work they do is great. They have many great partners and benefactors and maintain excellent relationships with them. Most employees and volunteers are happy and valued.
cons: Some management is disorganized. They seem to be understaffed and always in need of help. Some processes are inefficient and could be done in better ways.

pros: The people are nice. The work environment is very friendly. Also, they have free food most of the time.
cons: The tasks are the exact same everyday. It is just basic tasks around the house. It can get very repetitive. Sometimes the supervisors might write a task more than once so they can keep the volunteers busy.

pros: since im only 17 its a good pay for me. the position i work it tailored to my capability, which is great
cons: a challenge is making sure costomers are happy and satified with our work and time. costomers are sometimes very picky and choosey.

pros: Pay was decent, people were decent, plus it has cheap food if you want to eat some during your lunch break, and you could get time off pretty easily
cons: Food actually makes me really sick, training wasn't very much if at all, some of the people weren't decent

review_title: Great Concept but Management is Disorganized
pros: They really do care about their guests, and it is generally a pleasant place to be.
cons: Scheduling and finding coverage was incredibly difficult. There is also a disconnect between management and guest relations.

pros: Everyone is very friendly..Great to help many families in their time of distress.
cons: Working with one rotten apple makes a big difference in work environment that's why there's a big turn around in employees, leaves to wonder why that apple is still there.

pros: I can only speak for my local chapter.  I loved working for this organization. Upper management was supportive of my career goals and the work life balance was incredible. I remain close to my former coworkers.
cons: I would have liked to have more feedback on my personal performance and measurable goals.

job_title: Confirmation Team Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: Knowing you are helping people,  working with the public, helping parents
cons: Takes a toll on your emotional  health seeing unwell children and worried parents,  feels like you can’t do enough to help parents or poor sick kids

pros: At RMHC -HI you help families in need and feel very connected to your community.
cons: Incredibly stressful work environment with poor time management  coming from above. There are very difficult personalities  and an unwillingness to make positive changes to procedures.

pros: The mission is amazing! Helping families in the most critical time of need is the most fulfilling. The staff and volunteers are incredibly friendly and I enjoyed going to work everyday.
cons: Compensation was not fair. We worked a lot of overtime and were not compensated appropriately.

job_title: IT and Computer Support Volunteer in Philadelphia, PA

pros: Involved in amazing work helping families that are going through a tough time in their lives.  Felt good to help people out and make a difference.

pros: Great atmosphere, great people.  This company understand the point of team environment, really enjoyed working here. Great pay.

pros: Overall learning experience was amazing. Being able to work so closely with this organization was well worth it being a non paid internship. Very hard working people in a fun environment.
